intro: Hibiscus teramnensis, commonly known as the swamp hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to wetland areas of the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its large, showy flowers that typically range in color from white to pink or red. The plant has heart-shaped leaves and thrives in moist, swampy environments. Hibiscus teramnensis is a perennial herb that often grows in dense clusters along the edges of ponds and rivers. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and wetland conservation efforts.
